quick_answer.what: Karangetang, also known as Api Siau, is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,797 m (5,896 ft) at the northern tip of Siau Island in the Sangihe Archipelago, North Sulawesi, Indonesia.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 2023. One of Indonesia's most frequently active volcanoes with over 60 recorded eruptions since 1675.
quick_answer.famous_for: Its extraordinarily persistent eruptive activity, including frequent pyroclastic flows and lahars that have repeatedly devastated villages on the small, densely populated island.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — approximately 22,000 people live on Siau Island, many within direct hazard zones of pyroclastic flows and lahars.

overview.content: Karangetang, locally known as Api Siau ("Fire of Siau"), is an active stratovolcano rising to 1,797 m (5,896 ft) at the northern end of Siau Island in the Sangihe Archipelago, approximately 125 km north-northeast of the northeastern tip of Sulawesi in Indonesia. It ranks among Indonesia's most persistently active volcanoes, with more than 60 eruptions documented since 1675 — a frequency surpassed by few volcanoes on Earth. The volcano dominates tiny Siau Island, which measures only about 17 km long and 8 km wide, yet supports a population of approximately 22,000 people, many living within direct reach of its pyroclastic flows and lahars. Karangetang's summit is crowned by five craters arranged along a north–south line, several of which have hosted lava dome growth in recent decades. The volcano sits along the Sangihe Volcanic Arc, generated by the westward subduction of the Molucca Sea Plate beneath the Sangihe microplate. Its andesitic to basaltic-andesitic magma produces a volatile mix of explosive Strombolian and Vulcanian eruptions, lava dome extrusion, and gravity-driven pyroclastic flows that can reach coastal settlements within minutes. In the broader context of Indonesian volcanism, Karangetang's eruption frequency is comparable to Semeru and Merapi, though it receives far less international attention due to its remote island setting.

geology_and_formation.content: Karangetang owes its existence to the unusual double-subduction tectonics of the Molucca Sea region, where the Molucca Sea Plate subducts both westward beneath the Sangihe Arc and eastward beneath the Halmahera Arc. This rare convergent collision zone produces a chain of volcanic islands stretching from Mindanao in the Philippines southward through the Sangihe Archipelago. Siau Island itself is essentially the emergent portion of the Karangetang volcanic edifice, which rises roughly 3,000 m from the seafloor. The volcano is built of alternating layers of andesite and basaltic andesite lava flows interbedded with pyroclastic deposits — a classic stratovolcano construction. Its five summit craters testify to a complex history of vent migration and dome growth. The main crater (Crater I, or South Crater) and Crater II (Kawah Dua, or North Crater) have been the most historically active. Lava domes have repeatedly grown within these craters, only to collapse and generate pyroclastic flows that race down deeply incised valleys toward the coast. The steep flanks, carved by tropical rainfall into narrow ravines, act as efficient channels for both pyroclastic flows and rain-triggered lahars, amplifying the hazards well beyond what the relatively modest eruption magnitudes might suggest.

eruption_history_overview.content: Karangetang has one of the longest continuous eruption records of any volcano in the Sangihe Arc, with 62 recorded eruptions spanning from 1675 to 2023. Eruptive activity has been remarkably persistent: the volcano was active in every decade of the 20th century and shows no sign of slowing in the 21st. Most eruptions fall in the VEI 1–2 range, characterized by Strombolian explosions, ash emissions, and incandescent rockfalls, though VEI 3 events in 1675, 1972, 1983, 1999, and 2010 produced significant pyroclastic flows and destruction. The volcano's eruptive style alternates between phases dominated by explosive summit activity and periods of lava dome growth with subsequent collapse. Since the mid-20th century, activity has shifted among the various summit craters, with Craters I and II hosting the most vigorous episodes.

subsections.title: The 1675 Eruption — First Recorded Activity
subsections.content: The earliest documented eruption of Karangetang occurred in 1675, rated VEI 3. European colonial records from the period note significant explosive activity and devastation on Siau Island, though detailed accounts are sparse. This eruption established the volcano's reputation as one of the most dangerous in the Sangihe chain and marked the beginning of an eruption record that would grow to become one of the most extensive in Indonesia.

subsections.title: The 1976 Eruption — Deadly Lava Flows
subsections.content: A 1976 eruption produced lava flows on the south flank from an elevation of approximately 1,100 m and generated activity at the summit. While rated VEI 2, this eruption demonstrated the threat posed by effusive activity on the steep, inhabited flanks of the island. Pyroclastic flows generated by the collapse of advancing lava fronts reached populated areas, resulting in casualties and destruction of agricultural land. The event underscored the vulnerability of Siau's coastal communities to volcanic hazards originating high on the edifice.

subsections.title: The 1983 and 1999 Eruptions — Major VEI 3 Events
subsections.content: Two VEI 3 eruptions bookending the final decades of the 20th century caused significant damage. The 1983 event involved activity at both the summit and the southwest flank at 1,443 m elevation, producing pyroclastic flows that reached the coast. The 1999 eruption was similarly energetic, generating pyroclastic flows and heavy ashfall. Both events prompted evacuations of thousands of residents. Lahars triggered by heavy rainfall on freshly deposited tephra compounded the destruction for weeks after the eruptions themselves subsided.

subsections.title: The 2010–2012 Eruptions — Prolonged Crisis
subsections.content: Beginning in 2010, Karangetang entered a prolonged eruptive phase that lasted intermittently through 2012. The 2010 eruption, rated VEI 3, centered on Crater I (the South Crater) and produced the most significant pyroclastic flows in recent decades. These fast-moving density currents swept down river valleys toward coastal settlements, killing at least four people and forcing the evacuation of over 1,000 residents. Subsequent VEI 2 activity from Craters I and II in 2011–2012 maintained elevated alert levels and disrupted life on the island for years.

subsections.title: 2018–2023 — Continuing Activity
subsections.content: The volcano remained persistently active through 2018–2023, with eruptions from both the North and South summit craters. Multiple episodes of lava dome growth, Strombolian explosions, and pyroclastic flows were observed. A 2021 VEI 2 eruption produced pyroclastic flows that again threatened communities, while the most recent confirmed eruption in 2023 (VEI 0) involved activity from the Main (South) Crater. The volcano's alert level has been raised and lowered repeatedly during this period, reflecting the unpredictable cycling between dome growth and explosive phases.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Karangetang is monitored by Indonesia's Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG), which operates seismic stations, tiltmeters, and visual observation posts on Siau Island. The volcano's alert level fluctuates frequently between Level II (Waspada/Advisory) and Level III (Siaga/Watch), reflecting its near-continuous low-level activity punctuated by escalations. Satellite-based thermal monitoring regularly detects hotspots at the summit craters, indicating ongoing fumarolic activity or incipient dome growth even during officially quiescent periods. Given the volcano's track record of erupting in nearly every decade since records began, PVMBG considers another eruption not a question of 'if' but 'when.' The primary monitoring challenge is the volcano's remoteness and the difficulty of maintaining instrumentation on the steep, jungle-clad slopes.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Karangetang presents an outsized hazard relative to its eruption magnitudes because of the combination of steep topography, deeply incised river valleys, and the close proximity of populated settlements. Pyroclastic flows generated by lava dome collapse can travel from the summit to the coast — a distance of roughly 5 km — in under ten minutes, leaving minimal evacuation time. Lahars, triggered when heavy tropical rainfall mobilizes loose volcanic debris, represent a secondary hazard that can persist for months or years after an eruption. The island's limited infrastructure compounds the risk: Siau has only narrow coastal roads, a small harbor, and no airport, making large-scale evacuation by sea the only realistic option. With roughly 22,000 people sharing the island with one of Indonesia's most active volcanoes, Karangetang ranks among the highest-risk volcanic settings in the archipelago. PVMBG has established hazard maps delineating danger zones along the major river valleys, and evacuation drills are conducted periodically, though the practical challenges of island-based emergency response remain formidable.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Siau Island is a small volcanic island in the Sangihe Archipelago of North Sulawesi Province. Karangetang's summit, at 1,797 m (5,896 ft), constitutes the highest point and forms the dramatic northern skyline of the island. The volcano's five summit craters are aligned on a roughly north–south axis, reflecting an underlying structural control. The upper slopes are steep and barren, scarred by frequent pyroclastic flows and incandescent rockfall tracks. Below approximately 1,000 m, dense tropical vegetation covers the flanks, intersected by deeply carved river valleys that serve as natural conduits for lahars and pyroclastic flows. Coconut and clove plantations dominate the lower elevations, extending to the narrow coastal plain where most of the island's population resides. The surrounding Molucca Sea waters are deep, and the submarine portion of the Karangetang edifice is considerably larger than the emergent island.

cultural_significance.content: The name Karangetang derives from the local Sangirese language, while its alternative name Api Siau translates to "Fire of Siau," reflecting the volcano's central role in the cultural identity of the island's inhabitants. The people of Siau have coexisted with their volcano for centuries, and its periodic eruptions are woven into local oral traditions. Despite the hazards, many residents are reluctant to permanently relocate, drawn by the fertile volcanic soils that support productive clove and coconut cultivation — Siau is one of Indonesia's top clove-producing regions. The volcano's persistent glow and steam plumes are visible landmarks for fishermen navigating the surrounding waters, recalling the Aleut navigational traditions associated with volcanoes in other parts of the Pacific.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Karangetang is the most active volcano in the Sangihe Volcanic Arc, a chain that extends from Mindanao in the Philippines southward past Siau to the northeastern tip of Sulawesi. Other notable volcanoes in the region include Awu on Great Sangihe Island to the north, which produced a catastrophic VEI 4 eruption in 1711 that killed over 3,000 people, and Ruang volcano to the south. The broader volcanic context of Indonesia includes more than 120 active volcanoes, of which Karangetang's eruption frequency places it in the top tier alongside Semeru, Merapi, and Dukono.

facts: Karangetang has erupted more than 60 times since 1675, making it one of the most frequently active volcanoes in all of Indonesia.
The volcano's alternative name, Api Siau, translates to 'Fire of Siau' in the local Sangirese language.
Siau Island, entirely dominated by the Karangetang edifice, measures only 17 km by 8 km yet supports roughly 22,000 residents.
Five summit craters are aligned on a north–south axis across the peak — an unusual configuration reflecting deep structural controls.
Pyroclastic flows from the summit can reach the coast in under ten minutes due to the volcano's steep flanks and short run-out distance of approximately 5 km.
Siau Island is one of Indonesia's largest producers of cloves, cultivated on the fertile lower slopes of the volcano.
The volcano sits on the Sangihe Volcanic Arc, formed by the rare double subduction of the Molucca Sea Plate beneath both the Sangihe and Halmahera arcs.
Karangetang was active in every single decade of the 20th century, with 37 recorded eruptions between 1900 and 1999.
The submarine base of the Karangetang edifice rises approximately 3,000 m from the seafloor, making the total structure far larger than the visible island.
Evacuation from Siau Island must occur by sea, as the island has no airport — a major constraint on emergency response planning.

faqs.question: Is Karangetang volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Karangetang (Api Siau) is one of the most active volcanoes in Indonesia. Its most recent confirmed eruption occurred in 2023, and it has produced over 60 eruptions since records began in 1675. The volcano was active in every decade of the 20th century. Indonesia's PVMBG monitors Karangetang continuously, and its alert level frequently fluctuates between Advisory and Watch status. Volcanologists consider future eruptions virtually certain given its persistent activity pattern.

faqs.question: Where is Karangetang volcano located?
faqs.answer: Karangetang is located at the northern end of Siau Island in the Sangihe Archipelago, part of North Sulawesi Province, Indonesia. The island lies approximately 125 km north-northeast of the northeastern tip of Sulawesi in the Molucca Sea. Its precise coordinates are 2.781°N, 125.407°E. The volcano dominates the small island and is the highest point in the entire Sangihe chain at 1,797 m (5,896 ft).

faqs.question: How dangerous is Karangetang volcano?
faqs.answer: Karangetang is considered one of Indonesia's most dangerous volcanoes due to the combination of frequent eruptions, steep topography, and the close proximity of approximately 22,000 residents on Siau Island. Pyroclastic flows can travel from the summit to the coast in under ten minutes. The island's lack of an airport means evacuation must occur by sea, severely limiting emergency response options. Multiple eruptions in recent decades have caused fatalities, property destruction, and forced evacuations of thousands of people.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Karangetang?
faqs.answer: Karangetang is a stratovolcano (also called a composite volcano), built from alternating layers of lava flows and pyroclastic deposits. Its magma is andesitic to basaltic-andesitic in composition. The volcano features five summit craters and produces eruptions ranging from effusive lava dome growth to explosive Strombolian and Vulcanian events. It formed through the subduction of the Molucca Sea Plate beneath the Sangihe microplate.

faqs.question: How tall is Karangetang?
faqs.answer: Karangetang's summit reaches 1,797 m (5,896 ft) above sea level, making it the highest point on Siau Island and in the Sangihe Archipelago. However, the total height of the volcanic edifice is much greater: it rises approximately 3,000 m from the seafloor of the Molucca Sea. By comparison, it is taller than many well-known Indonesian volcanoes such as Gamalama at 1,715 m but shorter than giants like Semeru at 3,657 m.

faqs.question: What was Karangetang's worst eruption?
faqs.answer: The most destructive recent eruption occurred in 2010, when a VEI 3 event produced pyroclastic flows that killed at least four people and forced the evacuation of over 1,000 residents from coastal villages. The 1983 and 1999 eruptions, also rated VEI 3, caused significant damage and prompted large-scale evacuations. Historical records from earlier centuries are less detailed, but the first recorded eruption in 1675 (VEI 3) was noted for causing devastation on the island.

faqs.question: How often does Karangetang erupt?
faqs.answer: Karangetang is one of the most frequently erupting volcanoes in the world. Since records began in 1675, it has produced over 60 confirmed eruptions — an average of roughly one eruption every 5–6 years. In the 20th century alone, 37 eruptions were recorded, averaging one every 2–3 years. Activity ranges from minor ash emissions to significant VEI 3 explosive eruptions with pyroclastic flows.
